DataElement.preferredName: Product Alteration Antibody Administered Specify Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The free-text field to describe the antibodies administered during product (e.g.,human drugs; therapeutic biologics; allergenics; cells, tissue and gene therapy products; blood components and blood derivative products) manipilation.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A thing produced by or resulting from a process. EXAMPLE(S): drug, device. The FDA list of regulated products: animal and human drugs; therapeutic biologics; allergenics; cell, tissue and gene therapy products; blood components; blood derivative products; devices; and animal (pets and livestock) and human food/feed (medicated and un-medicated); cosmetics; pet treats; and dietary supplements._A change resulting in something that is different from the original._A type of protein made by B lymphocytes in response to a foreign substance (antigen). Each antibody only binds to a specific antigen, helping to destroy the antigen directly or by assisting white blood cells to destroy the antigen._The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The end result of a manufacturing process; anything that is produced.:A change resulting in something that is different from the original.:A protein made by plasma cells (a type of white blood cell) in response to an antigen (a substance that causes the body to make a specific immune response). Each antibody can bind to only one specific antigen. The purpose of this binding is to help destroy the antigen. Some antibodies destroy antigens directly. Others make it easier for white blood cells to destroy the antigen.

Concepts.definition: The end result of a manufacturing process; anything that is produced.
The act or process of modifying something.

A type of protein made by B lymphocytes in response to a foreign substance (antigen). Each antibody only binds to a specific antigen, helping to destroy the antigen directly or by assisting white blood cells to destroy the antigen.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).
